title: Aaron Rodgers' connection with Aaron Jones powers Packers past Chiefs for win
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Believe it or not we have all but reached the halfway point of the NFL regular season. As Lorenzo Reyes details, the league's elite class is starting to crystalize. USA TODAY

KANSAS CITY, Mo.— The Arrowhead crowd still looked red and gold, but “Go Pack go” cheers boomed across the stadium.

Wherever Packers fans were, they liked what they saw from Aaron Rodgers, even as no one knew what the quarterback himself saw on the play. One minute into the fourth quarter, Rodgers had already taken five sacks, the most he’d endured since Week 1, and 11 hits. Not one but two Chiefs pass rushers closed in. But Rodgers heaved a pass toward the right sideline as he fell to the ground. His ball soared over tight end Jimmy Graham near the sideline in the end zone. But Packers running back Jamaal Williams was positioned just perfectly in the end zone corner behind Graham. Williams grabbed the ball, stepped in and maintained control even as he, too, toppled.

The score sealed the Packers’ win, improving their record to 7-1 this season. The Chiefs fell to 5-3, and 1-3 at home.

Aaron Rodgers doing Aaron Rodgers things. (Via @NFL) pic.twitter.com/SjrroXPDEY — USA TODAY NFL (@usatodaynfl) October 28, 2019

Here are three things we learned in the 31-24 Green Bay win:

1. The Packers' running backs stepped up

The Packers’ top receiver Davante Adams missed a fourth straight game with turf toe. But each week, Rodgers and the Packers unflinchingly find weapons to use to eke out wins. Against the Chiefs, it was a night for running backs. Aaron Jones, who broke out against the Cowboys in Week 5 with four touchdowns, added two more via passes from Rodgers to take the NFL lead with 11 scores this season. Jones had a career-high 226 yards from scrimmage, including 159 receiving on seven catches. Williams rushed for another score early in addition to his corner catch. On a night when the Chiefs generated relentless pressure, capitalizing on his running backs was a key for Rodgers’ production.

2. The Chiefs offense works without Patrick Mahomes

We’ve seen the script from the Saints, Colts, Panthers and Jaguars already this season. They lost, respectively, quarterbacks Drew Brees, Andrew Luck, Cam Newton and Nick Foles. Backup passers stepped in, and the teams continued to win. Moore didn’t win this contest, but the veteran whom Kansas City signed two months ago to the day—he wasn’t on an NFL roster in 2018 and was coaching high school football in California in August—did far more than just manage the offense as he connected with the Chiefs’ talented offensive pieces.

Coach Andy Reid schemed a creative game for Moore to spread the ball around to Tyreek Hill, Travis Kelce, LeSean McCoy, Mecole Hardman and Sammy Watkins. Moore executed that plan with poise as the Chiefs scored on a lob, a shovel pass and a handoff. But like they did on Moore’s third-and-2 pass on Kansas City's first drive, the Chiefs came up short on the night overall.

3. Kansas City’s defensive performance against the Broncos wasn’t a fluke

The Chiefs sacked Joe Flacco nine times in their last matchup, the Oct. 17 Thursday Night Football game in which Mahomes dislocated his right knee cap. Again, against the Packers, the defense was solid, though it allowed too many big plays. If the blitz can continue to be this effective, and Moore can continue to connect with Chiefs pieces as he did against the Packers, Mahomes' already-shortened recovery timeline will seem even shorter.

Follow Jori Epstein on Twitter @JoriEpstein.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders.
description: The Chiefs pushed the Packers despite being without Patrick Mahomes, but Green Bay's backfield led the way to secure a key victory.
